the, the numbers are still very skewed to say the least.

You think the problem is not enough doctors?

And you think there are plenty of doctors?

and I do know that O B, which is my field --
-- the doctors' health in-, the doctors' malpractice insurance is over two hundred thousand dollars a year --

What do you think about the, uh, Peace Corps or public service commitment?
Uh, that's the first I've ever heard of it.

like the Conservation Corps back in the thirties or, uh, various other things of that sort.

and some people would get civilian, uh,
I assume it's the kinds of things that they had conscientious objectors do,

or farm work in World War One I remember --

It seems like you'd have a lot more conscie-, conscientious objectors if they had that choice.
you know, I'd, I'd much rather work in a hospital than, than to go war

Well, I think that in the, in the cases that, like that, uh, they had to be, uh, pretty thoroughly examined to prove that they had pacifist and religious beliefs and so forth,
and that this wasn't something new just to keep out of going to war.
It was, uh, something that was a fundamental part of their philosophy of life.
And then you run into, again, to, um, the bureaucracy in running it.
You know, how you going to --
-- cover that many people because we've got a lot more people now than we did then --
in addition to that, we have the cost because you have to pay something for,
and then you have to pay them some kind of a stipend,
uh, even if it's like the Peace Corps where they don't get most of it until they come home,
you have t-, have to pay them something.
that would be expensive in most cases.

-- and it really did seem to be a worthwhile organization,
but on the other hand, I'm not sure what the permanent value of it was.
know what we got for all the money.

and to, uh, Algeria and to, uh, Southeast Asia and lots of, uh, out-of-the-way places.
